title: What does it mean to be a refugee? - Benedetta Berti and Evelien Borgman

multiple-choice.question: According to the 1951 UN Convention relating to the status of refugees, what is the definition of a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and unable to return due to well-founded fears of persecution.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone who is internally displaced and unable to return to their home country.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who is seeking asylum in a new country.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is fleeing economic hardship.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a migrant and a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: A migrant is someone who is fleeing conflict, while a refugee is someone who is seeking economic opportunities.

options.label: B
options.text: A migrant is someone who is seeking economic opportunities, while a refugee is someone who is fleeing conflict.

options.label: C
options.text: A migrant is someone who is internally displaced, while a refugee is someone who is outside their country of nationality.

options.label: D
options.text: A migrant is someone who is seeking asylum, while a refugee is someone who has been granted asylum.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why refugees are forced to entrust their lives to smugglers to cross borders?

options.label: A
options.text: Limited access to shelter, water, or food.

options.label: B
options.text: Financial and political factors that prevent them from traveling by standard routes.

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of funding for education programs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of refugee camps?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide long-term shelter and integration into the host country.

options.label: B
options.text: To offer short-term shelter until inhabitants can safely return home, be integrated into the host country, or resettle in another country.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide education programs for refugee children.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide humanitarian aid to refugees.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first legal step for a displaced person in a new country?

options.label: C
options.text: To be integrated into the host country.

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle preventing a nation from sending an individual to a country where their life and freedom are threatened?
What is the most basic obligation towards refugees?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide education programs for refugee children.

options.label: B
options.text: To guarantee a minimum standard of treatment and non-discrimination.

multiple-choice.question: What is the issue with many refugee children?

options.label: A
options.text: They are out of school due to lack of funding for education programs.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not permitted to enter the workforce.

options.label: C
options.text: They are fully dependent on humanitarian aid.

multiple-choice.question: What is the definition of a refugee in the context of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and unable to return due to well-founded fears of persecution.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone who is internally displaced and unable to return to their home country.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who is seeking asylum in a new country.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is fleeing economic hardship.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of remembering the stories of refugees?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps to provide them with the support and protection they need to rebuild their lives.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to understand the complexities of the issue.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to raise awareness about the issue.

title: Are You A Good Listener?

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is always wrong to disagree with someone

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is always right to criticize someone who is wrong

options.label: C
options.text: Because being wrong is not the same as being disliked

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is always easy to agree with someone

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What are biofilms composed of?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A process where microbes compete with each other for resources

options.label: D
options.text: A process where microbes form a single, unified organism

title: Why is the US Constitution so hard to amend? - Peter Paccone

multiple-choice.question: What is the minimum number of states required to ratify a constitutional amendment?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the country has become more unified

options.label: B
options.text: Because the country has grown larger and more diverse

options.label: C
options.text: Because the founders wanted to make it harder

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Lowering the thresholds required for proposal and ratification

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the number of states required to ratify an amendment

options.label: C
options.text: Making the Constitution easier to repeal

options.label: D
options.text: Making the Constitution easier to interpretAnswer: A: Lowering the thresholds required for proposal and ratification

options.label: A

options.text: Because the country has grown larger and more diverse

options.label: C
options.text: Because the founders wanted to make it harder

options.label: D

title: Does grammar matter? - Andreea S. Calude

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between prescriptivists and descriptivists have in their approach to language?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescriptivists think language should follow consistent rules, while descriptivists see variation and adaptation as a natural part of language.

options.label: B
options.text: Descriptivists think language should follow consistent rules, while prescriptivists see variation and adaptation as a natural part of language.

options.label: C
options.text: Both prescriptivists and descriptivists think language should follow consistent rules.

options.label: D
options.text: Both prescriptivists and descriptivists see variation and adaptation as a natural part of language.

options.label: D
options.text: Speech is less formal than writing.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The approach that thinks language should follow consistent rules.

options.label: D
options.text: The approach that sees variation and adaptation as a natural part of language.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The debate between prescriptivism and descriptivism is not a real debate.

options.text: To allow broader communication and ensure that people in different parts of a realm could understand each other.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The prescriptivist approach tries to understand and map differences without dictating correct ones, while the descriptivist approach tries to establish a common language for all people.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The prescriptivist approach sees variation and adaptation as a natural part of language, while the descriptivist approach thinks language should follow consistent rules.

options.label: D
options.text: The prescriptivist approach thinks language should follow consistent rules, while the descriptivist approach sees variation and adaptation as a natural part of language.

title: 5 tips to improve your critical thinking - Samantha Agoos

multiple-choice.question: What is critical thinking, and how can it help us make informed decisions?

options.label: A
options.text: Critical thinking is a way of approaching a question that allows us to carefully deconstruct a situation, reveal its hidden issues, and make the best decision.

options.label: B
options.text: Critical thinking is a way of approaching a question that allows us to make quick decisions without thinking.

options.label: C
options.text: Critical thinking is a way of approaching a question that allows us to ignore information that we don't want to hear.

options.label: D
options.text: Critical thinking is a way of approaching a question that allows us to make decisions based on emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first step in the five-step process for critical thinking?
What is the purpose of formulating a question in critical thinking?

options.label: C
options.text: To identify what you are looking for

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of applying the information in critical thinking?
What is the purpose of considering the implications in critical thinking?

options.label: C
options.text: To think about the long-term effects of your decision

options.label: D
options.text: To explore other points of view

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of exploring other points of view in critical thinking?

options.label: C
options.text: To ask yourself why others might hold a different opinion

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using critical thinking?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us make quick decisions without thinking.

options.label: B
options.text: It can help us ignore information that we don't want to hear.

options.label: C
options.text: It can give us the tools to sift through a sea of information and find what we're looking for.

options.label: D
options.text: It can make the world a more unreasonable place.

multiple-choice.question: What is the five-step process for critical thinking?

options.label: A
options.text: Formulate a question, gather information, apply the information, consider the implications, and explore other points of view.

options.label: B
options.text: Gather information, apply the information, consider the implications, explore other points of view, and formulate a question.

options.label: C
options.text: Formulate a question, apply the information, consider the implications, explore other points of view, and gather information.

options.label: D
options.text: Gather information, consider the implications, explore other points of view, apply the information, and formulate a question.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of subjecting all available options to scrutiny and skepticism in critical thinking?
What is the ultimate goal of critical thinking?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the world a more unreasonable place.

options.label: B

title: The beneficial bacteria that make delicious food - Erez Garty
